body.head: f 109v (27 August) ( Shooting tournament and other games)

div.ab: The xxvij day of august ther was a tentt se vp at ffynsbere ffeld ffor my lord mare & ye enbassadurs & ye masters ye altermen & mony commenars & ther w the shutyng of ye standard for ye best game & dy odur dyd shut for odur games after ye wyche was to be wrastelyng bathellmuw day & iij sondays after

row.cell: Item we presente and also find mr medcalf for stoping the Comon sewer ageinst his houses in the old strete, and all along his gardeins and to pay for every pole in length
Item we presente and also find the said mr medcalfe ageine for a noying a certein Dich with wedes and Rubish betwene the Londes of the said medcalf & the Londes of Iohn Hilliard
ITem we presente and also find William Gill gardinour hath purchaised of Thomas Langham ffishmonger a certen cottaige with a garden lieng in whitcrosstret on the west sid & paieth yerely

div.ab: Item we presente & also find mr medcalf for that he hath incroched a dich that belongeth to Iohn hilliard & Iohanna his wief which ledeth betwene the gardens that the said medcalf holdeth of the Chamber of London & the Londes of the said Iohn & Iohanna his wief now called Glosseters gardeins

Item we presente and also finde mr medcalfe for anoying of a certen dich with wedes and Rubishe betwext the londes of late william wakefeild & now in thandes of Iohn hilliard often tymes presented & not amended

To the iij iiij v. vj vij. viij. ix. x. xj. we know nothing/
To the xij we know not whether the alley betwene the gardeins of the lordship of ffynnysbury/ and the londes of Iohn medcalfe be parcell of the mannour of ffynnysbury But we knowe the same Alley was a thorowghe faire tyme out of mynde & we thinke it to be a partie Alley

We presente yat William Gill gardinor is ded since the last Courte and that Katherin his wiefe is Tenaunte for terme of her liefe and after her decease to one Danyell Gill thelder and his heires foreuer

row.cell: ITem we presente that Katherin Gill is ded since the last Courte and yat Daniell Gill thelder dwelling in the ile of man is heire vnto all such Londes as William Gill did purchaise of Thomas Langham Browenbaker as appereth by the last will of the said William Gill/ which is a Cottaige with a garden in whitcrosstrete on the west side and payeth yerelie quiet rent

div.ab:
Item we ye homage fynde yat kateryn gyll wydow wydowe late ye wyffe of william gyll decessyd. who hylde certin landes or tenementes of ye lorde of this manomano:
letter lost due to trimming of ffynsburye for terme of hur lyf. ys deade & yat Danyell gyll ys nowe tenante to ye lorde of the same manour. of ye sayde landes & Tenementes bye the gyfte of ye sayde william gyll by his laste wylle & Testament./ & paythe yerelye quyttrente â€“ xxij d.

We finde that Iohn Medcofe skinner hathe of the citty by lease a parcell of grounde deuided into many gardens lyinge and beinge one the weste side of that parte of ffynsbury field called Bunehill field which pece of grounde adioyning to tenementes & gardenes supposed to be the free hold lande of his one neare vnto the highe waye leadinge from Pictehedge to shorddiche Cshurche Churche: C written over s And that their is an Alle betwene the said ground of the Cittie and the said subposed to be free lande of the said Medcaulfe whervppon he hathe over theaste ende of the same Alle builded or suffered to be builded by his Tennauntes
a newe howse the southe ende of which howse standeth into the gardenes belongine to the Cittie twoo fete & a half in lenghte westwardes .xiiijtine fute & a half or their aboutes. wherfore wee presente him for the same. And likewiese for theaste side of the same howse stande into the felde caulled Bunehille field Nine Inches And that he hathe sett vpp a butteris of Bricke standinge into the said field three foute

Also wee presente the said Medcaulf land which he holdethe lyethe within the Mannour of ffynsbury but wether yt be holden of the Mannour or noe we knowe notte But that is within the circuite and boundes of the same Mannur

Wee finde that the true boundes of the Mannour of ffinsbury beginnethe at the southe weste corner of the gardens adoiyninge to the
ffarme howse of finsbury and goethe belonginge to the said mannor of ffynsbury and goethe Easte ward allonge one the southe side of the same gardens allonge thorowe the Alle which Alle is in the same Mannour and so alonge by the Ralle which separtes mallowe felde & more feld and so alonge by the southe ende of the gardens adoiyninge to More feld and so alonge by the southe ende of the gardens adoiyninge to More feld into a diche of watter called the comone sewer which runnethe into more diche. And from thence the same diche Northewarde alonge one theaste side the gardens belonginge to Iohn Worssopp and so alonge one theaste side of twoo closes of the same Iohn Worssopp nowe in the occupacion of Thomas Lee thelder buttcher for which gardens & Closses the said Iohn Worssopp payethe quitrent to the mannour of ffynsbury as aperethe by the Recorde. And so the same boundes g goe over the highewaye close by a barren latly builded by one Niccolles includinge the same barren and so northe as the comon sewer & waye goethe to the playehowse called the Theater And so tournethe by the same comon sewer to Dame agnes the clere And then the same boundes turne weste wardes as the way goethe to the new howses latly builded by Humffry Toye/ which is heald by lease of the Cittie for three yerely Rente of xx s. which howses standethe one theaste side of the waye leadinge from Aldersgate strett and so turninge to Islingeton by Charter howse walle
And then the same boundes turne southe ward towardes Aldersegatt includinge Didimus Bucklandes groundes howefarre for furder wee doe not well know But wee finde that diuers quitrentes ar and haue bene payed to the same Mannour for landes lyinge in Goswell, Barbicaine, Redcrossteret, gouldinge lane, Bechlane, Whitecrosstret, Cheswell strete, and Grubstrete, aswell within the fredom of the Cittie of London as without/
Although this 1586 inquest describes the then boundaries of the manor of Finsbury, the playhouse mentioned is the Theatre, in Shoreditch.
we present yat Danyell gyll is at his sute fyne & is to paye xij d. for his Absens at this cowrte.

ab.note: The Names of e Defalteres this corte.

div.ab: Daniell Gylle

We doe preasentt that where at a covrte holden at ffynsbury in Anno .1586. yt was supposed that Iohn medcalfe. should be one of the Lordes Tennanttes. of this Mannor/ the sayd Iohn mettcalfe hath shewed further vnto vs. this preasentt day. A Deade Dated the Laste day of septembar .Anno. xxxvjth of henry the eighte made by one Thomas Buttcher .gentelman. vnto Roger Mettcalfe. of one Aker. and thre Roddes. of Lande with the Apurtenances Lyinge and beeinge with in the parishe of St Glyles withowt crypplegate. Late in the tennor of one Iohn. Rastall. and allso in the occupacyon of the sayd Roger Medcalfe. which Aker &. iij Roddes. of Land. aperes. by this Deade ys holden of the Late monestary. of hallywell as allso further apperith. by the kinges Lettares. pattentes. which he wilbe Redy to shewe at all tymes when yt shall please. ye steward for the Lorde to cale for the same
And that other Landes he holdes not with in this mannor. other wise then by Lease. which he hath from the Lorde of this mannor
We presente that Danyell gyll is at his sewte fyned and not to be Amersyd payinge .xij d. for every cour cour: letter lost due to cropping

head.title: Governors of Bridewell's Court Book
head.seg: Bethlem Royal Hospital Archives and Museum: BCB â€“ 04

div.ab: Iohan Ienninges who lodgeth with one Goodwief Kinge nere the playehouse in White crosse streete examined saieth she lodged theare half a yere but for as muche as she cannot geue a good accompt howe she lyveth she is ponished and kept till furder order/.
The playhouse in question was almost certainly the Fortune in Golding Lane, a short distance from Whitecross Street.

ab.note: De Concessione licencie pro Thoma Downton & alijs.

div.ab: Iames by the grace of God &c To all Iustices Maiors Sheriffes ʌbailiffes Constables headboroughes and other our officers and loving subiectes greeting knowe ye that wee of our especiall grace certaine knowledge and meere mocion haue licenced and authorized and by theise presentes doe licence and authorize Thomas Downton Thomas Towne William Byrde Edwarde Iuby Samuell Rowle humfrey Ieffes Charles Massey and Anthonie Ieffs servauntes to our dearest sonne the Prince and the rest of theire Associates to vse and exercise the arte and facultie of playing Commedies Tragedies histories Enterludes Morralls Pastoralls Stageplayes and such other like as they haue alreadie studied or hereafter shall vse or studie aswell for the recreacion of our lovinge subiectes as for our solace and pleasure when wee shall thincke good to see them during our pleasure And the said Commedies Tragedies histories Enterludes Morralls pastoralls stageplaies and suche like to shewe and exercise publiquelie to their best Commoditie aswell within theire nowe vsuall house called the the: written over erasure ffortune within our Countie of Middlesex as alsoe within anie Towne Halls or Moutehalls or other convenient places within the libertie and ffredomes of anie other Cittie vniversitie Towne or Boroughe whatsoeuer within our Realmes and Domynions willing and Commaundinge you and everie of you as you tender our pleasure not only to permitt and suffer them herein without anie your lettes hindraunces or molestacions during our saide pleasure but alsoe to be aiding and assisting vnto them yf anie wrong be to them offered And to allowe them such former curtesies as hath been given to men of theire place and quallitie And alsoe what further favour you shall shewe vnto them for our sake wee shall take kindelie at your handes Prouided alwaies and our will and pleasure ys that all auctoritie power priuiledges and profittes whatsoever belonging and properlie appertaining to the Maister of our Revells in respecte of his office and everie Clause article or graunte conteined within the lettres patentes or Commission which haue heretofore been graunted or directed by the late Queene Elizabeth our deere Sister or by our selves to our welbeloued servants Edmonde Tilney Maister of the office of our said Revells or to Sir George Bucke knighte or to either of them in possession or reversion shall be remayne and abide entire and in full force estate and vertue and in as ample sorte as yf this our Commission had never been made In witnesse whereof &c witnesse our selfe at westminster the Thirtith daie of Aprill. extracta
per brreve de priuato sigillo &c

This licence was printed in E.K Chambers and W.W. Greg (eds), â€˜ Dramatic Records from the Patent Rolls. Company Licences,â€™ Collections 1, pt 3, Malone Society (Oxford, 1909), 268â€“9. It was also printed by T.E. Tomlins in the Shakespeare Societyâ€™s Papers, 4 (1849), 42, although it was mistakenly described as Privy Seal and misdated 1607. The Signet Bill itself is indexed under April 1606 in TNA: PRO SO3/3.

seg.idno: Bethlem Royal Hospital Archives and Museum

div.ab: Robert Netherwood brought in by warrant from the Sherifes of London by Anie one of theire officers for sondrie misdemeanours by him done vpon Shrovetusday it was testefeid against him that he said the day before that he would bringe 500 persons vpon Shrovetuisday to pull downe the ffortune playhouse & therevpon he examined said, that it was true, he said he would bringe fyve score for that purpose, but was in drincke when so he said he is by order of Court ponished and kepte att worke./

In his diary under the date of 24 March 1668, Samuel Pepys describes the riots at Shrovetide with 'the prentices, taking liberty of these holidays to pull down bawdy-houses… which is one of the great grievances of the nation' (The Diary of Samuel Pepys, Robert C. Latham and William Matthews (eds), vol 9 (London, 1976), 128â€“30). See the other Shrovetide riots in 1617/18.

Item wee finde, that ʌone Danyell Gill Thomas Hollyman late tenant of this Mannour hath since the last Court (as wee are informed) alyened a certen parcell of land betwene Golding lane & Whitecrosse street, vpon which a play howse is nowe buylt, Which he held of the same Mannour by the rent of xij d. & other seruices, vnto Edward Allyn, By reason whereof there is due vnto the lordes of this Mannour for a relief.

William Gill, 'gardinour,' first appears in the list of freeholders in 1551 or 1564 (it is unclear as to which date the list should be assigned). His death was reported to the Manor Court in November 1577, when Katherine his wife was to hold his lands for life, after which they were to descend to Daniel Gill the elder (pp 10 and 15). In 1582, and again in 1584, it was reported to the Manor Court that Katherine Gill (Gyll) had died and that Daniel Gill the elder, â€˜dwelling in the ile of Manâ€™ was heir, by will, to such lands as William Gill had purchased from Thomas Langham, brownbaker, which 'is a Cottaige with a garden in whitecrosstrete on the west side,' for which he paid a yearly quit rent of 22d (pp 15 and 19).

This is the first and only record that Edward Alleyn attended Finsbury manor court, when he was one of ten jurors whose names were bracketed together. He signs his name on p 70, ' Ed Alleyn.' Between 1615â€“26 his name regularly appears in the list of defaulters who are fined for not attending the manor court (pp 79, 81â€“3, 85â€“6, 88, 90, 92, 94, 97, and 99), and it appears in error in 1630 (p 108), by which time he was dead.

hi.add: Memorandum quod vndecimo die Ianuarij Anno Decimo et xlvj Iacobi Regis istud Breve Deliberatum fuit Domino Cancellario Anglie apud westmonasterium exequendum./

div.ab:
JAMES by the grace of God King of England, Scotland, ffrance and Ireland defendour of the faith &c To our right trusty and welbeloved Counsellour Thomas Lord Ellesmere our Chauncellour of England greeting. Wee will and commaund yow that vnder our great Seale of England yow cause our lettres patentes to be made forth in forme following.
Iames Iames: in italic script by the grace of God &c. To all Iustices, Mayours, Sheriffes, Bayliffes, Constables, Headboroughes, and all other our Officers and loving Subiectes, greetinge, Knowe Knowe: in italic script yee that wee of our especiall grace certaine knowledg & meere mocion have licensed and authorized, and by theise presentes doe License and authorise Thomas Downton, William Bird, Edward Iuby Samuell Rowle, Charles Massey, Humfrey Ieffes, ffranck Grace, William Cartwright, Edward Colbrand, William Parr, William Stratford, Richard Gunell ʌIohn Shancke and Richard Price Servantes to our sonne in lawe the Elector Palatine Palatine: in italic script and the rest of their Associates, to vse and exercise the art and facultie of playing Comedies, Tragedies, Histories, Enterludes, Moralles, Pastoralles, Stageplayes and such other like, as they haue alreadie studied, or hereafter shall vse or studie, aswell for the recreacion of our loving Subiectes, as for our solace and pleasure, when wee shall thinke good to see them, during our pleasure. And the said Comedies, Tragedies, Histories, Enterludes, Moralles, Pastoralles Stageplayes and such like, to shewe and exercise publicquely to their best commoditie, aswell within their now vsuall howse called the ffortune within our County of Middlesex, as also within any Towne Halles, or Moutehalles or other convenient places within the libertie and freedome of any Cittie, Vniuersitie, Towne or Borough whatsoever within our Realmes and Dominions. Willinge and commaundinge yow and every of yow as yow tender our pleasure, not only to permitt and suffer them herein without any your Lettes, hinderanes or molestacions during our said pleasure; but also to be ayding and assisting vnto them, if any wrong be to them offered, And to allowe them such former curtesies, as hath been given to men of their place and qualitie; And alsoe what further favour yow shall shewe vnto them for our sake, wee shall take kindly at your handes. Prouided Prouided: in italic script alwaies and our will and pleasure is, That all authoritie, power, priviledges and proffittes whatsoever belonging and properly apperteyning to the master of our Revelles, in respect of his office, and every clause, article or graunt conteyned with in the lettres patentes or Commission, which haue been heretofore graunted or directed to our welbeloved servant Sir George Buck knight master of our said Revelles, shalbe remayne and abide entire and in full force estate and vertue, and in as ample sorte as if this our Commission had never been made. In wittnes In witnes: in italic script whereof &c. Given vnder our privie Seale at our Pallace of Westminster the sixth day of Ianuarie, in the Tenth yeare of our raigne of England ffraunce and Ireland, and of Scotland the sixe and thirtiethfortieth./. thirtieth: for fortieth
Receptum .11. Ianuarij .1612

Downton
Players.
Extractum Commission/

Iames by the grace of god &c To all Iustices Mayors Sheriffes Bayliffes Constables headborroughes and all other our officers and lovinge subiectes greetinge knowe yee that wee of our speciall grace certayne knowledge and meere mocion haue licenced and aucthorized, and by these presentes doe license and aucthorise Thomas Downton, William Bird, Edward Iuby Samuell Rowle, Charles Massey humfrey Ieffes, ffranck Grace, William Cartwright, Edward Colbrand, William Parr William Stratford Richard Gunell Iohn Shancke and Richard Price servauntes to our sonne in lawe the elector Palatyne and the rest of their associates to vse and exercise the arte and facultie of playinge Comedies, tragedies, histories Enterludes Morralles Pastoralles Stageplayes and suche other like, as they have alredy studyed or hereafter shall vse or study aswell for the recreacion of our lovinge subiectes as for our solace and pleasure, when wee shall
thinke good to see them, during our pleasure, And the said Comedies tragedies histories Enterludes Morralls Pastoralls, Stageplayes and such other like to shewe and exercise Publickly to theire beste commoditie aswell within theire nowe vsuall house called the ffortune within our County of Middlesex, as also within anye towne halls, or moutehalls or other convenient places within the libertie and freedome of any Cittie, vniuersitie Towne or borrough whatsoever within our Realmes and Dominions willinge and commaundinge you and euerye of you as you tender our pleasure not onely to permitt and suffer them herein without any your lettes, hynderaunes or molestacions duringe our said pleasure, but also to be aydinge and assistinge vnto them, yf anye wronge be to them offered, And to allowe them suche former curtesies, as hath bene geven to men of their place and qualitie, and also what further favoure you shall shewe vnto them for our sake, we shall take kindly at your handes. Prouided alwayes and our will and pleasure is, that all auctoritie power priuiledges and profittes whatsoever belonginge and properly appertayninge to the Master of our Revelles in respecte of his office and euery clause article or graunt conteyned with in the letters patentes or Commission which have beene heretofore graunted or directed to our welbeloved seruaunt Sir George Buck knight Master of our said Revells, shalbe remayne and abyde entire and in full force estate and virtue, and in as ample sorte as yf this our Commission had never been made In witnes whereof &c. witnes our selfe at westminster the eleventh daye of Ianuarye.
per breve de priuato Sigillo

This licence was printed by E.K Chambers and W.W. Greg (eds), â€˜ Dramatic Records from the Patent Rolls. Company Licences,â€™ Collections 1, pt 3, Malone Society (Oxford, 1909), 275â€“7. The Signet Bill, misdescribed as a Privy Seal, was printed by Collier, H.E.D.P, vol 1, p 366, and Hazlitt, English Drama and Stage, p 44.
The sequence in the MS strongly suggests that the date, given as '1613,' is in error for '1615.'

body.head: sigs B3â€“B3v ( William Fennor tells of his challenge to Kendall to a contest at the Fortune playhouse)

div.ab:
And let me tell thee this, to calme thy Rage.
I chaleng'd Kendall on the Fortune Stage;
And he did promise 'fore an Audience,
For to oppose me; note the Accidence:
I set vp Bills, the People throng'd apace,
With full intention to disgrace, or grace:
The
The The: also printed as a catchword at the foot of B3 House was ful, the Trumpets twice had sounded,
And though he came not, I was not confounded,
But stept vpon the Stage and told them this;
My Aduerse would not come: not one did hisse;
But flung me Theames: I then extempore
Did blot his name from out their memorie,
And pleasd them all, in spight of one to braue me,
Witnesse the Ringing Plaudits that they gaue me.
Item we fynde Edward Bleytoun gentleman Robertus Iackson Ricardus Shrawley Thomas Walton and Edward Allen armiger haue not had suffycient warninge of this Court

row.cell:
xij
: monetary abbreviation lost due to cropping

div.ab: p 85 (5 October)

row.cell: Francis Michell gentleman Edward Allen esquire Richard Wotton gentleman for not appearance in
Francis Michell gentleman Edward Allen esquire Richard wotton gentleman for not apparance at this Courte and amerced in

div.ab: Item they doe present Edward Allen for not apperinge at this Courte in ij s. per polle
Item wee doe present Edward Allen esquire in vj d. per poll for not appereinge at this Courte to doe their suite & service
The homage doe present at this Courte thexecutors & oversers of Edward Allin are amerced in xij d. per poll for not apperinge at this Courte to do their seuerall suites & seruices.
p 104* (Freeholdersâ€™ inquest: new tenants)

Item the homage doe present that Iames Travers gentleman one of the Tenutes of this Mannour dyed before this Courte & that Iames Travers is his second sonne vnto whome the landes hereafter mencioned are bequevethed by the last will & Testament of the said Iames Travers deceased, & that the said Iames Travers deceased dyed seised of a little parcell of Comen grounde in whitecrosse street late in the tenure of Iohn Hillyard & before in the tenure of Iohn Worsopp vpon which parcell of grounde divers tenementes have bene & nowe are lately erected & builted, nowe or late in the seuerall enures or occupacions of Richard Gonnell, Mathewe Smithe Iohn Massey Richard Stratford, widowe Baseley Richard Browne, widow Butler, Iohn Palmer, Charles Browne, Walter Hill, Aveline Bradley widowe, widowe Aveice, widowe mason widowe wade, & Thomas Browne for which said tenementes & premisses the said Iames Travers did doe his ffealtie & that xij d. per Annum quittrent is due to the lordes of this Manor.
The new tenements erected in Whitecross Street were now occupied by various players at the Fortune playhouse.

Item Thomas Allyn Maister Mathias Allin warden of the Colledge named Godsguifte in dulwich in the Countie of Surrey appeared at this Courte & have given in evidence to the Courte that the landes late of Edward Allin esquier deceased holden of this Mannour scituate in whitecrosse streete & in Goldinge lane which the playhowse called the fortune, (which tenementes in whitecrosse street are nowe in the severall tenures of Roger Iveson Richard Hill Iohn Gibbs Iohn Harte & divers others & of Thomas Pitts Mr Iohnson Willyam Weason & Gyles Turke in Golding lane) All which landes were given in Mortmayne by licence, by the said Edward Allen for & towardes the maintenance of the Colledge abovesaid & that there is (blank) per Annum quittrente due for the presmises.

The wardens (or master and governors) of 'godsguifte colledge' were fined for non-appearance at the Manor Court in 1632, 1634, and 1636, the heirs of Edward Alleyn in 1633, the governors (or masters) and wardens of 'Godsguifte at Dulwich' in 1637â€“42, 1645â€“8, 1652â€“6, 1658â€“9, and still in 1857. Edward Allin, gentleman, appears as a defaulter from 1642 for several years, only in 1646 at the same time as the Dulwich College wardens, but he was probably a different man from the actor (pp 112, 116, 120, 124, 126, 128, 132, 140, 144, 146, 148, 150, 153, 157, 172, 175, 177, 179, 184, 192, 203, 220).
At this Courte Edward Allin esquire are amerced in vi d. per poll for not appeareinge at this Courte to doe their suite and services./
At this Courte the Master & Governors of Godsguifte Colledge are amerced in iiij d. per poll for not appereinge at this Courte do doe their seuerall suites & services
At this Courte the Master & Governours of Godsguifte Colledge for not appereinge at this Courte to doe their suite & service and amerced in iiij d. per poll

Item the homage doe fynde that before this Courte Mr Iames Trave Trave: letters lost due to cropping & others did bargaine sell & conveye vnto the vicear & Churchwardens of St Gyles without Creplegate London & their Successors a certaine parcell of grounde in Whitecrossestreete neare the Fortune Playehowse in mortmayne which is converted & vsed for a Churchyard to buy the deade in & at this Courte Iohn Bowman one of the Churchwardenes of the said parishe Churche did appere at this Courte & doe his fealtie for himseffe & the rest of the feoffees for the said parcell of grounde./
At this Courte the Governour & wardens vj d. of Godsguifte at Dulwich are amerced as on their heades appereth for not apperinge at this Courte to doe their suites & services,
At this Courte the Master & wardens of Godsguift College ʌ2 d. for not appereinge at this Courte to doe their severall sutes & services are amerced as on their heades appereth.
At this Courte the Governour iiij d. & wardens of Godsguift Colledge at Dulwich for not appereinge at this Courte to doe their serveral suites & services are amerced as on their heades appereth.
At this Courte the Governour & wardens of Godsguift 4 d. at Dulwich for note apperinge at this Courte to doe their seuerall suites & services are amerced as on their severall heades appereth.
At this Courte the Governour & wardens ij d. of Godsguifte Colledge for not apperinge to doe their severall suites & services are amerced as on their severall heades appereth./.

At this Courte Thomas Allen Master of Gods guift Colledge in Dullwich did his fealty for the landes he holdeth & the rest of that Corporacion holde of this Mannour now in the tenure of Anthony Hancock or his assignes scittuate in Golding lane & Whitecrosse streete within the said Mannor And to pay xxij d. yearly quitrent

The Difference betweene Edward Thicknes and Thomas Allen Master of Dulwich Colledge Concerning a ʌ brick wall on the south side of the Playhouse yarde beweenebetweene beweene: for betweene & golding Lane hath beene viewed by vs whose names are vnder wrytten doe finde that the said brick wall doth belong to Dullwich Colledge aforesaid./
